subject: If I Had a Hammer...
event: ... I'd hammer some more on Kong, actually. Hey, but I CAN have a hammer. And so can you, thanks to the good folks at Valyrian Steel, who have just unveiled their design for King Robert's warhammer. Alas, you can't order the hammer just yet. We're still in the design stage, but I have approved these drawings, so the next step is the prototype, which is now being made. Once I approve that, production can begin. And along about there somewhere, Valyrian Steel will begin taking orders. For more details, check out their website at http://www.valyriansteel.com/ Yes, it is a big hammer. A very big hammer. Going to be heavy as well. I insisted on that. After all, it says right in the book that Robert's warhammer was so huge and heavy that only someone with his own freakish strength could wield it. So I kept telling them, "bigger, bigger." Valyrian Steel has done some lovely versions of Longclaw, Needle, and Ice (all of which remain available from their store), but I think the hammer is my favorite to date.

comments.article: I prefer swords but the detail...oh that is amazing.
That's an amazing design. Mjolnir ain't got nothing on it.

Except that Mjollnir was forged by dwarfs, wielded by a god, and regarded by the Gods as their best weapon against their numerous foes. :-x

Robert's warhammer is cool, but not that cool!

comments.subject: I saw Mjolnir at Wal-Mart yesterday

comments.article:
I thought once: "It'd be really cool to own a copy of Needle."

But seeing that... I... I want that.

I hope that by the time its up for sale I have the cash.
I don't see a lot of love between my brothers and my sisters all over this land happening with that beast.  But it's gorgeous!
Oh baby.  That's pretty awesome.
I've loved and wielded hammers in stage combat for years. This is a must purchase for me. Beautiful piece. Looks very close to what I had pictured in my head!

LOVE.

as much as I liked the swords, and would want to own one of the swords, I absolutely LOVE this warhammer.
despite the description, in my minds eye, I always pictured it smaller.

I think I may have to own this one.

"Barring tsunamis, general strikes, world wars, or asteroid strikes, you will have the novel in your hands on July 12. I hope you like it."

So it's your fault we're having all these natural disasters!lol I wonder where the asteroid is going to hit? I couldn't resist! My best friend got me hooked on your books and I've been waiting on pins and needles for the next one!
comments.subject: Publication date

comments.article:
Very pretty cat in your pic. is it a classic tabby, like the ones I've been seeing in commercials a lot recently?


Anyway, I prefer swords too, but I always get stuck playing as a cleric when playing anything D&Dish with my friends... so I am used to imagining hammers in combat.
comments.subject: Re: I'm in love...

comments.article: oooh...shiny! :)
Am I the only one who doesn't like the spiky head on it? I just kind of figured the head of the hammer would be smoother than that. It seems to jar with the rest of the design (which is quite good)
Warhammers always had spikes.  It was part of what made them so deadly.
Beautiful, and perfect.  It has more sledgehammer than classic warhammer in its ancesty, and it's exactly what I've always pictured Robert carrying.

One of the comments on the Valyriansteel website states that the stag should not be crowned on the hammer since he was not yet king when he used it on the trident.  I don't remember it saying in the book whether the crown was added only after Robert won the throne.  Was the crowned stag the sigil of house Baratheon before the rebellion?  Or was it just a stag?
comments.subject: Quick question...

comments.article: Why is the stag already crowned? If it's Robert's hammer from when he killed Rhaegar, he wasn't king yet, so the stag shouldn't be crowned.
comments.subject: The graphic is wrong

comments.article: The Baratheons took the arms of the Storm Kings who came before them.
comments.subject: Re: The graphic is wrong

comments.article: Do they offer customization? Money is not an issue. I want a model 3 times the size in bulk, to hang from the ceiling (steel reinforced rafters, very safe). This would be perfect to complete my mead hall.
Umm, you could really hurt a guy with that!

That is a VERY unrealistic warhammer, but I do not care! I want one! I want two.. one for each hand. I'll probably need to get cybernetic arms to swing them, but that's okay.. those are on my wishlist too.
oh wow ,the way i imaginated it is way diferent!
Spike on the handle look very unsafe for 2-handed weapon. But since when Robert was about safety :-)

While the left part of the etching, with the antlers and crown, do look like a crowned stag, I think that the overall, with the thingies on the right side, actually looks more like a kraken.
When I first saw the hammer picture, I believed that the right part was a squid's head, with the left part (the antlers) being its arms
comments.subject: Stag or... Kraken?

comments.article: Meh. I am still amazed that Longclaw was approved. That plastic transformer wolf is a bit of an eyesore.

I dunno about comparing this to a poleaxe, your link goes to poleaxes. A poleaxe was typically 5 feet in length. This does not look 5 feet long. It looks closer to 3.5 or 4 feet max.

Have you ever seen someone who is much stronger than you? I'm a small guy and I can only press 2 plates max. For me, wielding something like that would be comical. But I've seen folks in the gym that can press 5 plates (that's 495 pounds). These people can also curl 150-175 pounds. They aren't even pro body builders, but they could swing something that's 20-25 pounds without breaking a sweat.

There are freakishly strong men out there and I highly doubt that this weapon was supposed to be practical. I'm assuming Robert was one of those guys with arms the circumference of your average man's head. So I'll stay a believer that Robert's war hammer is this big.
comments.subject: comparing apples to oranges?

comments.article:
Sorry for the off-topic, but I have been to the NYC HBO store yesterday. The exhibition is really nice. There is plenty of gowns and armors, as well as other artifacts (maps, cups, seals, etc.), which were all actually used during filming (at least as the HBO people swear). Particularly cool are the Jamie's armor and Sandor's hound-helmet.

As regards the offered merchandise, it is not yet very developed. There are few different kinds of t-shirts (all the houses arms, plus tv series logos with crows), but they offer so far male models, and they are all of pretty poor quality. The shop assistants claims that it's all gonna change in 2 weeks, when they will deliver the whole new bunch of gadgets and clothes.

One of the employees said that he is lobbying at the merchandise department to make a hooded sweatshirt, where the hood would be a hound's head and there would be "Beware of the Hound" sing on the back of the sweatshirt. How do you like the idea?
I am picturing a most pleasant experience of road rage, exiting my car with Robert's hammer, and watching the expression of the guy that cut me off.

I have to agree with Jakevti. We suspend our disbelief for dragons, Others, Wildlings, Dothraki, and other things (no spoilers here, but you all know the things taht go on in George's world), but we're going to moan over weapons?

It's been awhile since I've read AGoT, but in the early chapters it described Robert as being six and a half feet tall and when he fought Rhaegar he was around 280 pounds of muscle. I distinctly recall Ned saying when he wore his great stag helmet he was a beast of a man on the battlefield and that he, Ned, could barely lift Robert's hammer, let alone swing it.

Robert was a 6'6, 280 pound giant in his prime. He can wield unseemly weapons. We all know Rhaegar was no slouch, but Robert still fought him and we know how that ended. He seems more than capable of swinging an ungodly hammer like this in battle.

And I want one.
comments.subject: I love it

comments.article:
Honestly, yes, I can suspend my disbelief for a dragon but not for a stupidly large warhammer. Why? A dragon is clearly fantastical. It's not like there are real dragons to compare it to and say "well clearly this dragon is not a realistic dragon." There are no real sorceresses to compare to and say, "well obviously this is not a realistic sorceress."

War hammers, and other weapons, are the opposite. They are real things that are governed by real rules. Robert's war hammer wasn't magic. I mean, the whole reason Robert used a war hammer is for a realistic reason - real plate and mail is pretty effective against swords. It's hard to stick a guy in the joint bits. A hammer will transmit the impact force through the armor, or a spike on the hammer - like Robert's - can penetrate more effectively than a sword.

Those are REALISTIC considerations. So when we see the hammer it's disappointing that... it's not realistic at all. It's not that it's "oh that's kind of big for a war hammer" or "oh I guess a really big guy like Robert could wield it", no. It's so big that it's impossible that any non-magical human could wield it.

As for all the people saying, "Well Robert was really big!", that's actually more the reason this hammer is annoying. Bigger men are comparatively WORSE OFF in armored combat, not better. That's actually why I love that one chapter towards the end of the 2nd book - with our favorite little person outside King's Landing? Smaller men are actually better off when everyone is wearing armor. The weight of the armor needed to cover a larger man increases exponentially, because his surface area increases. But his strength increase proportionally - it increases at much a slower rate. Endurance decreases as well, since the larger body is all the less efficient.

This isn't to say big men aren't stronger and potentially faster. They may well be - if you want to see some really scary fast huge guys, watch sumo. But plate and mail fitted to their size is going to counter much of that natural advantage. An oversized war hammer isn't going to be necessarily easier for them to use.

(This is the same reason you don't see exoskeletal creatures like beetles and crabs grow past a certain size, except under water with buoyancy to assist.)

So in other words, Robert being huge is all the more reason he SHOULDN'T be able to wield an "oversize" hammer. Not that maybe he couldn't wield a relatively larger one - but it is NOT an argument in favor of it.

One of the things that is so nice about ASOIAF is the normally high level of historical detail and realism - the lack of typical fantasy silliness, or, as someone called it, the "MMO/anime" vibe. This war hammer is disappointing because it feels exactly that "MMO/anime" vibe.
comments.subject: Re: I love it
